:''For other uses, see [[The Politician (disambiguation)]]'' {{Politics}} A '''politician''', '''political leader''', or '''political figure''' (from Greek "[[polis]]") is a person who is involved in [[politics|influencing public policy and decision making]]. This includes people who hold decision-making positions in government, and people who seek those positions, whether by means of [[election]], [[inheritance]], [[coup d'état]], [[appointment]], [[electoral fraud]], [[Right of conquest|conquest]], [[divine right of kings|divine right]], or other means. Politics is not limited to [[governance]] through public office. Political offices may also be held in corporations, and other entities that are governed by self-defined political processes or can be known as freedom fighters.
== Considered a politician ==
* People who are [[Political activist|politically active]], especially in [[party politics]]. A person holding or seeking political office whether [[election|elected]] or [[appointed]], whether professionally or otherwise. Positions range from [[Homeowner association]]s<ref>[http://www.legal-explanations.com/definitions/homeowners-association.htm Legal-Explanations.com]</ref>{{Dubious|date=August 2012|reason=need source saying that members of homeowners associations are considered politicians}} and [[Neighborhood watch|block watches]]<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/neighborhood+watch Block Watch]</ref>{{Dubious|date=August 2012|reason=need source saying that members of neighborhood watch units are considered politicians}} to [[Executive (government)|executive]], [[legislative]] and [[judicial]] offices of [[Government|state and national governments]].<ref>[http://www.yourdictionary.com/politician politician - Webster's New World College Dictionary]</ref> Some law enforcement officers, such as [[sheriffs]], are considered to be politicians.
* Politician can be a term used in a derogatory manner to belittle a [[wikt:statesman|statesman]].<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/politician Dictionary.com]</ref>
== Public choice theory == [[Public choice theory]] involves the use of modern [[economic]] tools to study problems that are traditionally in the province of [[political science]]. (A more general term is "[[political economy]]", an earlier name for "economics" that evokes its practical and theoretical origins but should not be mistaken for the [[Marxian]] use of the same term.)
In particular, it studies the behavior of [[voters]], [[politicians]], and [[government]] officials as (mostly) self-interested [[Agent (economics)|agents]] and their interactions in the social system either as such or under alternative constitutional rules. These can be represented a number of ways, including standard constrained [[utility]] maximization, [[game theory]], or [[decision theory]]. Public choice analysis has roots in [[positive economics|positive analysis]] ("what is") but is often used for [[normative economics|normative]] purposes ("what ought to be"), to identify a problem or suggest how a system could be improved by changes in constitutional rules.<ref>Tullock, 1987, pp. 1040–41</ref> A key formulation of public choice theory is in terms of [[rational choice]], the agent-based proportioning of scarce means to given ends. An overlapping formulation with a different focus is [[positive political theory]]. Another related field is [[social choice theory]].
There are also [[Austrian Economics|Austrian]] variants of public choice theory (suggested by [[Mises]],<ref>Bureaucracy, Mises</ref> [[Friedrich Hayek|Hayek]], [[Israel Kirzner|Kirzner]], [[Lopez]], and [[Peter Boettke|Boettke]]) in which it is assumed that bureaucrats and politicians are benevolent but have access to limited information.
